text: [Music]

[Applause]
my story is a little bit about War uh
it's about disillusionment it's about uh
death uh and it's about rediscovering
idealism uh uh in all of that wreckage
and perhaps also there's a lesson about
how to deal with our our screwed up uh
fragmenting and uh dangerous world of
the 21st century um I don't believe in
straightforward narratives uh I don't
believe in a a life or history written
as decision a led to consequence B led
to consequence C these neat narratives
that we're presented with and that
perhaps we encouraging each other I
believe in Randomness and um one of the
reasons I believe that is because me
becoming a diplomat was random um I'm
colorblind I was born unable to see most
colors this is why I wear gray and black
most of the time and I have to take my
wife with me to uh to choose clothes and
um uh I'd always wanted to be a fighter
pilot when I was a boy I loved watching
planes Barrel over our holiday home in
the countryside um uh and I it was my
Boyhood dreamed to be a fighter pilot
and uh I did the test in the Royal Air
Force to become a pilot and sure enough
I fail you can't I couldn't see all the
blinking different lights I can't
distinguish color uh so I had to choose
another career and this was in fact
relatively easy for me because I had a
an abiding passion all the way through
my childhood which was international
relations as a child I read um the
newspaper thoroughly um I was fascinated
by the Cold War by the INF negotiations
over intermediate range nuclear missiles
uh the proxy war between the Soviet
Union and the US in uh Angola or
Afghanistan um these things really
interested me and so I decided at quite
an early age I wanted to be a diplomat
and I one day I announced this to my
parents and my father denies this story
to this day I said Daddy I want to be a
diplomat and he turned to me and he said
KH you have to be very clever to be a
diplomat and uh uh my ambition was
sealed uh uh uh 1989 uh uh I entered the
British Foreign Service uh that year
5,000 people applied to become a
diplomat and 20 of us succeeded and uh
as that as those numbers suggest uh I
was inducted into an elite uh and
fascinating and exhilarating World um uh
being a diplomat then and now is is an
incredible job and I loved every minute
of it I enjoyed the status of it I
bought myself a nice suit and wore
leather sold shoes uh and reveled in
this this this amazing access I had to
world events I um traveled to the Gaza
Strip I headed the Middle East peace
process section in the British foreign
Ministry I became speech writer for the
British foreign secretary I met Yas
Arafat I negotiated with uh uh satam's
diplomats uh at the un uh later I
traveled to carbal and served in
Afghanistan after the fall of the
Taliban and I would travel in a C130 uh
uh uh transport um and go and visit
Warlords in uh Mountain hideaways and
negotiate with them about how we were
going to eradicate Al-Qaeda from
Afghanistan surrounded by my special
forces ex escort who themselves had to
have an escort of a platoon of Royal
Marines because it was so dangerous uh
and that was exciting that was fun uh it
was really interesting and uh uh it's a
great Carter of people uh incredibly
close-knit community of people and the
Pinnacle of my career as it turned out
turned was uh was when I was posted to
New York
um I'd already served in Germany Norway
various other places uh but I was posted
to New York to serve on the UN Security
Council for the British delegation and
my responsibility was the Middle East
which was my specialty and there I dealt
with things like the Middle East peace
process um the lockerby issue we can
talk about that later if you wish um uh
but above all my responsibility was Iraq
and its weapons of mass destruction and
the sanctions we placed on Iraq to
oblige it to uh disarm itself of these
weapons um I was the the chief British
negotiator on this subject um uh and I
was steeped in the in the issue and uh
anyway uh uh my tour uh it was kind of a
very exciting time I mean it was very
very dramatic diplomacy uh we went
through several wars during my time in
New York um I negotiated for my country
the resolution in the security Council
of the 12th of September 2001 condemning
the attacks of the day before which were
of course deeply present to us uh
actually living in New York at the time
um so it was kind of a Best of Times
worst of times kind of experience um I
lived the high life I had uh although I
worked very long hours I lived in a
penthouse in Union Square I was a single
British Diplomat in New York City you
can imagine what that might have meant
um uh I had a good time uh but uh in 200
two when my tour came to an end um I
decided I wasn't going to go back um to
the job that was waiting for me in
London I decided to take a sabatical in
fact at the new school Bruce uh uh uh I
in some in coate inarticulate way I
realized that there was something wrong
with my work with me um I was exhausted
um and I was also disillusioned in a way
I couldn't quite put my finger on and I
decided to take some time out from work
um uh the foreign office was very
generous you could take these special
unpaid leave as they call them and yet
remain part of the Diplomatic service
but not actually do any work it was nice
um uh and eventually I decided to take a
cument to join the UN in
Kosovo uh uh which was uh then under un
Administration and two things happened
in Kosovo which kind of uh again shows
the randomness of life because these
things turned out to be one of the or
two of the pivots of my life and helped
Deliver Me To The Next Step age um but
they were random things one was that in
the summer of 2004 the British
government somewhat reluctantly decided
to have an official inquiry into the use
of Intelligence on wmd in the runup to
the Iraq War a very limited subject and
uh I testified to that inquiry in secret
um I had been steeped in the
Intelligence on Iraq and its wmd and my
testimony to the inquiry said three
things that uh the government
exaggerated the intelligence which was
very clear uh in all the years I'd read
it and indeed our own internal
assessment was very clear that uh Iraq
wmd did not pose a threat to its
neighbors let alone to us secondly the
government had ignored all available
alternatives to war which in some ways
was a more discreditable thing still um
the third reason I won't go into but
anyway I gave that testimony and that
presented me with a crisis what was I
going to do uh this testimony was deeply
critical of my colleagues of my
ministers um who had in my view
perpetrated a war on a falsehood uh and
so I was in crisis um and this wasn't a
pretty thing I moaned about it I
hesitated I went on and on and on to my
long-suffering wife um and eventually I
decided to resign from the British foral
service I felt there's a scene in the
alcino movie The Insider which you may
know where he goes back to CBS after
they've let him down over the uh the
tobacco guy and he goes you know I I
just can't do this anymore something is
broken and it was like that for me I
love that movie I I felt just
something's broken I can't actually sit
with my foreign minister or my prime
minister again with a smile on my face
and do what I used to do gladly for them
so I took a running leap and jumped over
the edge of a cliff and uh it was a very
very uncomfortable unpleasant feeling
and I started to fall and uh today that
fall hasn't stopped I'm still falling
but in a way I've got used to the
sensation of it and in a way I kind of
like the sensation of it uh a lot better
than I liked actually standing on top of
the cliff wondering what to do a second
thing happened in kovo which kind of I
need a a quick gulp of water forgive me
um a second thing happened in Kosovo
which kind of delivered the answer which
I couldn't really answer which
is what do I do with my life um I love
diplomacy I have no career my I expected
my entire life to be a diplomat to be
serving my country I wanted to be an
ambassador my mentors My Heroes were
people who got to the top of my
profession and here I was throwing it
all away I had a lot of my friends were
still in it um my pension was in it um
uh and I gave it up and what was I going
to do and that year in Kosovo this
terrible terrible thing happened which I
saw in March 2004 there were terrible
riots all over the province at it then
was of Kosovo 18 people were killed it
was Anarchy um and it's a very horrible
thing to see Anarchy to know that the
police and the military there were lots
of NATO troops there actually can't stop
that rampaging mob who's coming down the
street and the only way that rampaging
mob coming down the street will stop is
when they decide to stop and when
they've had enough burning and killing
and that is not a very nice feeling to
see and I saw it and I went through it I
went through those mobs um and with my
Albanian friends we tried to stop but we
failed and that Riot taught me something
um which isn't immediately obvious and
it's kind of a complicated story but one
of the reasons that Riot took place
those riots which went on for several
days took place was because the Kosovo
people were disenfranchised from their
own future there were diplomatic
negotiations about the future of Kosovo
going on then and the Kosovo government
let alone the Kosovo people were not
actually participating in those talks uh
there was this whole fancy diplomatic
system this negotiation process about
the Kosovo the future of Kosovo and the
kovos weren't part of it and funnily
enough they were frustrated about that
and those riots were part of the
manifestation of that frustration it
wasn't the only reason and life is not
simple one reason narratives it was a
complicated thing and I'm not pretending
it was more more simple than it was but
that was one of the reasons and that
kind of gave me the inspirational rather
to be precise it gave my wife uh who uh
the inspiration she said why don't you
ad the kosovars why don't you advise
their government on their diplomacy and
the kosovars were not allowed a
diplomatic service they were not allowed
diplomats they were not allowed a
foreign office to help them deal with
this immensely complicated process which
became known as the final status process
of Kosovo and so that was the idea that
was the origin of the thing that became
independent Diplomat the world's first
diplomatic Advisory Group and a
nonprofit to boot and it began when I
flew back from L from London after my
time at the UN with uh in Kosovo I flew
back and had dinner with the Kosovo
prime minister and said to him look uh
I'm proposing that I come and advise you
on the diplomacy I know this stuff this
is what I do why don't I come and help
you and he said raised his glass of
racki to me and said yes can't come and
uh I came to Kosovo and uh advised the
Kosovo government independent Diplomat
ended up advising three successive
Kosovo Prime Ministers and the
multi-party negotiation team of of
Kosovo and Kosovo became independent uh
independent Diplomat is now established
in five diplomatic centers around the
world and we're advising seven or eight
different countries or uh political
groups depending how you wish to Define
them and I'm not big on definitions
we're advising the northern cypriots on
how to reunify their Island we're
advising the burmes opposition the
government of southern Sudan which uh
you heard it here first is going to be a
new country uh within the next few years
um we're advising the polisario front of
the western Sahara who are fighting to
get their country back from an
occupation after 34 years of
dispossession we're advising various
Island states in the climate change
negotiations which is supposed to
culminate in
Copenhagen um there's a bit of
Randomness here too because when I was
beginning independent Diplomat I went to
a Party in the House of Lords which is a
ridiculous place but I was having
holding my drink like this and I bumped
into this guy who was standing behind me
and we started talking and he said um I
told him what I was doing and uh I I
told him rather Grand I was going to
establish independent Diplomat in New
York at that time that was just me and I
me and my wife were moving back to New
York and he said oh why don't you see my
colleagues in new New York and it turned
out he uh worked for a Innovation
company called what if which some of you
have probably heard of and uh one thing
led to another and I ended up having a
desk in whatif uh in New York when I
started independent Diplomat and
watching what if develop new flavors of
chewing gum for Wrigley or new flavors
for Coke actually helped me innovate new
strategies for the kovar and for the
Saharas of the western Sahara and I
began to realize that there are
different ways of doing diplomacy that
diplomacy like business is a business of
solving problems and yet the word
Innovation doesn't exist in diplomacy
it's all Zero Sum games and real politic
and ancient institutions that have been
there for generations and do do things
the same way they've always done things
and independent Diplomat today tries to
incorporate some of the things I learned
at what if we all sit in one office and
Shout at each other across the office we
all work on little laptops and try to
move desks to change the way we think
and we use um naive experts who may know
nothing about the countries we're
dealing with but may know something
about something else to try to inject
new thinking into the problems that we
try to address for our clients it's not
easy because our clients by definition
are having a difficult time
diplomatically um there are I don't know
some lessons from all of this uh
personal and political the and in a way
they're the same thing um the personal
one is um falling off a cliff is
actually a good thing and I recommend it
um and it's a good thing to do at least
once in your life just to tear
everything up and jump um the second
thing is is a bigger lesson about the
world today independent Diplomat is part
of a trend uh uh uh uh which is emerging
and evident across the world which is is
that the world is fragmenting uh States
mean less than they used to the power of
the state is declining uh that means the
power of other things is rising those
other things are called non-state actors
they may be corporations they may be
mafiosi they may be nice NGS they may be
anything any number of things uh we are
living in a more complicated and
fragmented world if governments are less
able to affect the problems that uh
affect us in the world
then that means who is left to deal with
them who has to take greater
responsibility to deal with them us um
if they don't can't do it who's left to
deal with it we we have no choice but to
embrace that reality um what this means
is is no longer good enough to say that
international relations or Global
Affairs or chaos in Somalia or what's
going on in Burma is none of your
business and that you can leave it to
governments to get on with I can connect
any one of you by Six Degrees of
Separation to the al-shabab militia in
Somalia to ask me how later particularly
if you eat fish interestingly enough um
but that connection is there we are all
intimately connected and this isn't just
Tom fredman it's actually provable in
case after case after case um what that
means is instead of asking your
politicians to do things you have to
look to yourself to do things and
independent Diplomat is a kind of
example of this in a sort of loose when
there AR AR neat examples but one
example is this the way the world is
changing is embodied in what's going on
at the place I used to work the UN
Security Council the UN was established
in 1945 its Charter is basically
designed to stop conflicts between
States interstate conflict today 80% of
the agenda of the UN Security Council is
about conflicts within States involving
non-state parties guerillas separatists
terrorists if you want to call them that
uh people who are not normal governments
who are not normal states that is the
state of the world today when I realized
this and when I look back on my time at
the security Council and what happened
with the kovar and I realized that often
the people who were most directly
affected by what we were doing in the
security Council weren't actually there
weren't actually invited to give their
views to the security Council I thought
this is wrong something has got to be
done about this so I started off in a
traditional mode uh me and my colleagues
an independent Diplomat went round the
UN Security Council we went around 70 UN
member states the kazaks the Ethiopians
the Israelis you name them we went to
see them the Secretary General all of
them and said this is all wrong this is
terrible that you don't consult these
people who are actually affected you've
got to institutionalize a system where
you actually invite the kosovars to come
and tell you what they think this would
allow you to tell you can tell them what
you think it would be great you can have
an exchange you can actually incorporate
these people's views into your decisions
which means your decisions will be more
effective and
durable super logical you would think I
mean incredibly logical so obvious
anybody could get it and of course
everybody got it everybody went yes of
course you're absolutely right come back
to us come back to us in um you know
maybe 6 months and of course nothing
happened nobody did anything uh the
security Council does its business in
exactly the same way today that it did
you know X number X number of years ago
when I was there 10 years ago so we took
we looked at that observation of
basically failure and thought what can
we do about it and I thought I'm
buggered if I'm going to spend the rest
of my life lobbying for these crummy
governments to do what needs to be done
so what we're going to do is we're
actually going to set up these meetings
ourselves so now independent Diplomat is
in the process of setting up meetings
between the UN Security Council and the
parties to the disputes that are on the
agenda of the security Council so we
will be bringing Dari Rebel groups
uh the northern cypriots and the
southern
cypriots uh uh Rebels from Arch um an
awful long laundry list of chaotic
conflicts around the world and we will
be trying to bring the parties to New
York to sit down in a quiet room in a
private setting with no press and
actually explain what they want to the
members of the UN Security Council and
for the members of the UN Security
Council to explain to them what they
want so there's actually a convers ation
which has never before happened and uh
of course describing all this any of you
who know politics Will think this is
incredibly difficult and I entirely
agree with you the chances of failure
are very high but it certainly won't
happen if we don't try to make it happen
and my politics has changed
fundamentally from when I was a diplomat
to what I am today and I think the
outputs is what matters not process not
technology frankly so much either tell
preach technology to all the twittering
members of the Iranian demonstrations
who are now in political prison in tan
where ammed NAD remains in power
technology has not delivered political
change in Iran you've got to look at the
outputs and you've got to say to
yourself what can I do to produce that
particular output that is the politics
of the 21st century and in a way an
independent Diplomat embodies that
fragmentation that change that is
happening to all of us
um that's my story thanks
